questions.text: At what age Handedness develops?
questions.solution: • Handedness develops by 3 years of age. Any early hand preference is abnormal.

choices.text: If the inner square is lighter than outer circle, use the vaccine
If the inner square is changing colour but still lighter than outer circle, use the vaccine
If the inner square is same as outer circle, use the vaccine
If the inner square is darker than outer circle, discard the vaccine

questions.text: Are all the following statements about the vaccine vial monitor correct except?
Best alternative to mother's breast milk in a LBW/preterm child is?
questions.solution: • The best source is Preterm mothers breast milk through direct breastfeeding, followed by (in sequence) expressed milk, drip breast milk, Human Donor breast milk, preterm milk formula, term milk formula, cow's milk.

questions.text: Drug used in severe covid infection in children
questions.solution: Reference: Guidelines of management of COVID in children, June 2021

questions.text: A child was brought with mental retardation. He had a Cherry red spot with no organomegaly. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Patients with the infantile form of Tay-Sachs disease have clinical manifestations in infancy including loss of motor skills, increased startle reaction, and macular pallor and retinal cherry-red spots.
  • Affected infants usually develop normally until 4-5 months of age when decreased eye contact and an exaggerated startle response to noise (hyperacusis) are noted. Macrocephaly, not associated with hydrocephalus, may develop.
  • In the 2nd year of life, seizures develop which may be refractory to anticonvulsant therapy. Neurodegeneration is relentless, with death occurring by the age of 4 or 5 years.
  • The juvenile and later-onset forms initially present with ataxia and dysarthria and may not be associated with a macular cherry-red spot.

questions.text: A 11-month-old child presented with incessant crying. On examination, a tender mass per abdomen was palpable in the right lumbar region. Barium enema imaging is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The child in the question has Intussusception that is confirmed with Claw sign in Barium enema.
  • Intussusception presents with sudden onset abdominal pain, excessive crying, red currant jelly stools and palpable sausage shaped mass in abdomen.
  • For confirmation, barium enema is done that shows Claw sign or Spring sign.
  • Pneumatic reduction must be performed as a surgical emergency. For ileo-ileal intussusception, we need surgical intervention as pneumatic reduction might not be possible

questions.text: A child with HIV presents with features of pneumonia. Which of the following organisms would be most commonly responsible?
questions.solution: • P. jirovecii (previously P. carinii) pneumonia is the opportunistic infection that led to the initial description of AIDS. This is one of the commonest AIDS defining illnesses in children; most cases occur between 3rd and 6th months of life.

questions.text: A child with cyanosis has the following CXR. identify the diagnosis?
questions.solution: • The x-ray shows a typical Snowman sign or Figure of 8 appearance or Cottage loaf heart. These are one and the same, seen in supracardiac TAPVC.

questions.text: APGAR score 3 at 1 minute indicates:
questions.solution:
APGAR is routinely measured at 1 min and 5 min.

0-3 = Severely depressed

4-6 = Moderately depressed

7-10 = Normal

questions.text: Phototherapy converts bilirubin to
questions.solution:
• Major product from phototherapy is a result of a reversible photoisomerization reaction converting the toxic native unconjugated 4Z,15Z-bilirubin into an unconjugated configurational isomer, 4Z,15 Bilirubin, which can then be excreted in bile without conjugation.
  • The other major product from phototherapy is lumirubin, which is an irreversible structural isomer converted from native bilirubin that can be excreted by the kidneys in the unconjugated state.

questions.text: In an unresponsive child with some signs of life present, head-tilt, chin-lift manoeuvre was performed. This manoeuvre to open the airway is contraindicated in which among the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Head-tilt, chin-lift manoeuvre is done to open the airway in an unresponsive child with signs of life present.

  • One hand is used to tilt the head, extending the neck.
  • The index finger of the rescuer's other hand lifts the mandible outward by lifting the chin.
  • Head-tilt should not be performed if a cervical spine injury is suspected.

questions.text: Not a component of VACTERL syndrome?
questions.solution:
VACTERL syndrome

  • V: Vertebral anomalies
  • A: Anal atresia
  • C: Cardiac defects
  • T: Tracheoesophageal fistula
  • E: Esophageal atresia
  • R: Renal and Radial anomalies
  • L: Limb defects

choices.text: Both macrosomia and large for gestational age

questions.text: A neonate was born through normal vaginal delivery at term. His birth weight was 3.8 Kg and was plotted on the chart in red, as shown in the figure. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
As seen in the image, the birth weight of the neonate has been plotted on the Lubchenco's Chart & since it is above 90th percentile, the diagnosis is Large for gestational age, LGA Baby. Also note that since the birth weight is <4 Kg, the baby is not having macrosomia.

  • Classification of neonates based upon centiles/charts (e.g., Lubchenco's or Fenton's Charts)- We take BW, Gest Age & then plot on a chart.
  • Interpretation
    1. Appropriate for gestational age (AGA): Between 10th to 90th centiles
    2. Small for gest age (SGA): Below 10th centile
    3. Large of gest age (LGA): Above 90th centile

Classification Of NeonatesBased upon birth weight (BW)

  1. Normal BW: 2.5 to 3.99 kg
  2. Low Birth Weight (LBW): Below 2.5 kg
  3. Very Low Birth Weight (VLBW): Below 1.5 kg
  4. Extremely Low Birth Weight (ELBW): Below 1 kg
  5. Macrosomia: 4 kg or above

questions.text: Look at the image and identify the associated genetic abnormality.
questions.solution:
The picture is showing a single transverse palmar crease, also known as simian crease. This physical finding is often seen in children with Down syndrome, also known as Trisomy 21.

Among the options given, option D suggests a male child with Trisomy 21 and is thus the answer.

questions.text: A child with fever presents with the following appearance, as shown. What complication can happen if this child also has an underlying chronic hematological disorder?
questions.solution:
Presence of fever along with bilateral erythematous flushing or papules on the cheek, producing slapped cheek appearance, suggests the likely diagnosis of Erythema Infectiosum, also known as Fifth Disease.

  • Complications include arthropathy, ITP, aseptic meningitis.
  • Individuals with chronic hemolytic anemia and increased red blood cell (RBC) turnover are very sensitive to minor perturbations in erythropoiesis. Infection with B19V leads to a transient arrest in RBC production and a precipitous fall in serum hemoglobin, often requiring transfusion. The reticulocyte count drops to undetectable levels, reflecting the lysis of infected erythroid precursors.
  • This can cause either pure red cell aplasia or sometimes transient aplastic crisis
  • These hematological complications are more common in Sickle Cell Anemia and Hereditary Spherocytosis when they get Parvovirus B19 infection.
  • Arthralgias are more common in adults, while complications like Pure Red Cell Aplasia (PRCA) and Transient Aplastic Crisis are more common in children and adolescents.

questions.text: Hallmark finding in IgA vasculitis is?
questions.solution:
Presence of palpable purpuric rash is a hallmark of HSP, seen in 95-100% of all patients.

Diagnostic criteria for HSP/IgA Vasculitis:

Palpable purpura (on buttocks & lower limbs) plus any 2 of the following

  • Diffuse Abdominal Pain
  • Tissue biopsy showing IgA deposits
  • Arthritis or Arthralgia
  • Renal involvement in the form of glomerulonephritis
  • the form of glomerulonephritis

questions.text: Treatment of choice in NEC Stage IIIB in an ELBW neonate who is extremely unstable and has DIC includes?
questions.solution:
Although Laparotomy with resection of gangrenous bowel and enterostomy formation is the standard procedure in most neonates with Stage IIIB of NEC owing to Perforation, this is not possible in ELBW unstable neonates.

  • Many ELBW neonates who are hemodynamically unstable and/or have complications like uncontrolled DIC cannot undergo immediate surgery.
  • They benefit from PPD- Primary Peritoneal Drainage, till the baby becomes stable & then surgery can be safely followed.

questions.text: A male child with 3 beta-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase deficiency cannot have which among the following?
questions.solution:
Congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to 3-beta hydroxy steroid dehydrogenase deficiency always produces ambiguous genitalia in both males and females.

  • Quick review: Features of 3-beta hydroxy steroid dehydrogenase deficiency and hormonal picture (Nelson 20th Ed)

questions.text: A neonate presented with complaints of bilious vomiting with minimal abdominal distension. His X-ray abdomen was done and is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Presence of bilious vomiting, no abdominal distension and X-ray abdomen showing a double-bubble appearance is suggestive of Duodenal Atresia as the likely diagnosis.

Regarding other options

  • Option B: Presents with triple bubble appearance and has bilious vomiting with abdominal distension
  • Option C: Presents with non-bilious vomiting and single bubble appearance on X-ray
  • Option D: Presents with non-passage or delayed passage of meconium beyond 48 hours and/or chronic constipation. Can also have abdominal distension.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most common cause of abdominal mass in a neonate?
questions.solution:
Multicystic dysplastic kidney- MCDK is the most common cause of an abdominal mass in the newborn, but the vast majority are nonpalpable at birth.

  • In most cases, it is discovered incidentally during prenatal sonography.
  • Contralateral hydronephrosis is present in 5-10% of patients. Sonography shows the characteristic appearance of a kidney replaced by multiple cysts of varying sizes that do not communicate, and no identifiable parenchyma is present.
  • Serial USGs done at 3 month initially and then every 6 monthly post infancy show regression of the cysts.
  • Most cysts resolve by 7 years of age.

questions.text: While at school, a 6-year-old boy is noted by his teacher to experience 10- to 20-second lapses in consciousness, sometimes with clonic movements of the face. His parents have not noticed this behaviour at home. Electroencephalography shows 3 per second generalized spike and wave discharges. The MOST appropriate therapy for this boy is:
questions.solution:
The diagnosis isAbsence Seizures

  • Absence seizuresare one of several kinds of seizures,seen across childhood, adolescence and adulthood.
  • Absence seizures are characterizedby a brief loss and return of consciousness, generally not followed by a period of lethargy(i.e., without a notable postictal state)
  • Hallmark is EEG showing 3 Hz (3/Sec) Generalized spikes and slow waves,also called asSpike & Dome patternof electrical discharges.
  • Treatment of patients with absence seizuresonly is mainly withvalproic acid or ethosuximide, which are of equal efficacy controlling absences in around 75% of patients.

questions.text: The weight of a child is quadrupled the birth weight at?
questions.solution:
Weight of a child isquadrupledthe birth weight by24 months.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child was diagnosed to have pneumonia. Which among the following shall be the therapy of choice?
questions.solution:
Most commoncause of pneumonia in school-going age is Mycoplasma pneumoniae.

  • For school-aged children and adolescents or when infection with M. pneumoniae or C. pneumoniae is suspected, amacrolideantibiotic is an appropriatechoice for outpatient management.
  • Azithromycinis generally preferred, whileclarithromycin or doxycycline (for children 8 yr or older) are alternatives.
  • For adolescents, a respiratoryfluoroquinolone (levofloxacin, moxifloxacin)may also be considered as an alternative if there are contraindications to other agents.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are correct
Both Assertion and Reason are incorrect
Assertion is correct but Reason is incorrect
Reason is correct but Assertion is incorrect

questions.text: Assertion: Mousy odour occurs in Phenylketonuria Reason: There is decrease in tyrosine, dopamine and noradrenaline in these patients causing this odour
questions.solution: Musty or mousy odour in Phenylketonuriaoccurs due to excretion ofPhenylacetate,a carboxylic acid, which is a metabolite excreted in urine in these patients.

questions.text: Which of the following is called Christmas disease?
questions.solution: Hemophilia B,also known asfactor IX deficiency or Christmas disease,is the second most common type ofhemophilia. The disorder was first reported in the medical literature in 1952 in a patient with the name of Stephen Christmas. The most famous family withhemophilia Bwas that of Queen Victoria of England.

choices.text: MR Vaccine s.c. on left arm & Oral Vit A, at 9 months completed
MR Vaccine s.c. on right arm & Oral Vit A, at 9 months completed
MR Vaccine s.c. on left arm & Oral Vit A, at 8 months completed
MR Vaccine s.c. on right arm & Oral Vit A, at 8 months completed

questions.text: A baby has received BCG at birth and has been vaccinated at 14 weeks. Which of the following shall be given on the next visit, along with route and site?
questions.solution:
As per National Immunization Schedule, the child will next requirevaccination at 9-12 months, i.e., 9 completed months of age. Vaccines given are

  1. MR Vaccine- Dose of 0.5 ml subcutaneously,given inright upper armat theinsertion of deltoid.
  2. Oral Vitamin A Drops-1 Lakh IU Given Orally

In addition,JE vaccineis given in endemic areas and since 2023, 3rddose offractional IPVhas also been introduced at9-12 months of age.

questions.text:
Increased pulmonary blood flow is seen in?
1.tTOF
2.tEbstein's Anomaly
3.tTGA
4.tTricuspid Atresia
5.tTAPVC
questions.solution:
Congenital Heart DiseasesBased UponPulmonary Blood Flow

  • Increased pulmonary blood flow
    • AllLeft to Right lesionslike ASD, VSD, PDA, ECD etc
    • TGA
    • TAPVC
    • Truncus Arterious
  • Reduced pulmonary blood flow
    • TOF
    • Tricuspid Atresia
    • Ebstein's Anomaly
    • Pulmonary Atresia
    • Eisenmenger Syndrome

Useful Tip For Integrated Pediatric-Radiology MCQS- Kindly note that all conditions withincreased pulmonary blood flow will show pulmonary plethora on CXR due to increased vascular markings,while all conditions with reduced pulmonary blood flow will havepulmonary oligemia on CXRdue to reduced vascular markings.

questions.text: A 6-year-old male was admitted with complaints of fatigue and mild joint pains. On examination, rash was found on the hands as shown in the image. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis is Juvenile Dermatomyositis.

  • Fatigue is anearly sign of muscle weakness. That along with the characteristic Gottron papules in the image suggest a diagnosis ofJuvenile Dermatomyositis.
  • Please note that as per Nelson 21stEd, 22-58% of JDM patients also have arthralgia and arthritis.

questions.text: A 6-week-old child has just received Pentavalent vaccine today. Components of Pentavalent vaccine shall include?
questions.solution:
Pentavalent vaccinesare given according to theNational immunization Program at 6-week, 10 week and 14 weeks.

  • It providesprotection against 5 vaccine preventable diseasesincludingDiphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus, Hepatitis B and H. Influenzae type b.
  • Pneumococcal vaccines and Fractional IPVare also administered along with this but are not part of pentavalent vaccine.

questions.text: Which among the following is the procedure of choice in aspirated foreign bodies in lower airway in children?
questions.solution:
Rigid bronchoscopyis bothdiagnostic and therapeutic procedurein childrenwho aspirate foreign body into the lower airway in children.

  • Flexible fiberoptic bronchoscopyis sensitiveto visualizebutcannotbe used toremove stuck FB.
  • As per Nelson 21stEd, "The treatment of choice for airway foreign bodies is prompt endoscopic removalwithrigidinstruments by a specialist (otolaryngologist or pulmonologist)."
  • Potential complications of rigid bronchoscopyincludebronchospasm, desaturation, bleeding, and airway edema,in addition to the inherent risks of anesthesia.
